Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a lot about migrant health and the theoretical frameworks used to evaluate it.
I learned salient theories in migration studies as well as a context for contemporary migration problems around the world.
Really great course where I learned a lot of information about public health and policies that affect immigrants.
Understanding of social epidemiology in the United States

I learned about the different theories, conceptual frameworks, and questions related to researching the health of migrants. Most importantly, I learned how to assess the implications of asking a question in a certain way and designing a research study in a certain way.

Going in, I only had a broad understanding of migration and did not know much about its relationship to health. I learned not only about the complex dynamic between health and migration but the various tools and theories to analyze these processes and relationships. I also learned why these types of studies are important and how the field still has a lot of work to do/grow.
Insights into modern health practices and how different migrant groups are affected by policy.
Great overall knowledge about health and migration, and all the theories and methods to study it
Learned to apply migration theories to the real life events that are occurring now with immigration.

This course is really well organized, and the material you need to know is made very clear, which I appreciated a lot. Studying the health of specific migrant populations was really interesting. I think it might be helpful to have more examples of applying the theoretical frameworks.
Good course but would have liked more in class exercises.

This course was great in regards to exploring research in this field and understanding the reasoning behind researchers' methods and the meaning of their results.  I think there could have more interaction with students during lectures, which would have made classes more engaging.  Some of the topics we discussed were not only interesting but also controversial, and I think it would have been great to have student discussions.  Another way to increase engagement, considering how focused this course was on looking at research within the field, is to have students work together to create a series of questions they would ask a group of immigrants to learn about a specific topic.

I think that the readings were an appropriate amount and that the assignments/exams were very fair. I greatly appreciated the slides being posted online and the review sessions for the exams. Professor Martnez was a great lecturer - her explanation of concepts was always thorough.

Maybe if the course was presented as a joint lecture-seminar, this may have primed people to participate more (ex: lecture style on Monday, seminar style on Wednesday). Another possible change would be to diversity the reading lists. In addition to academic papers, personal narratives or book excepts (like the one about Ciudad Juarez) could have added to our discussions. I also really enjoyed the guest speakers - unfortunate that the circumstances did not allow for more this semester.
Lecture style was not conducive to what could have been productive conversation. Subject material was interesting, wish it was more engaging.
Yes! Prof. Martinez is wonderful and it's a really interesting course.

I think migration is now a permanent part of 21st century life and it is important to understand it. Also, as someone focus in health, migration is an area that is often forgotten. Combining the two is an important intersectionality to be explored.
Would recommend even if the topic doesn't sound that interesting to you. I feel like I learned a lot of useful information.
Yes
Yes, the subject matter was interesting and well organized for learning

I would recommend this course to another who was interested in learning about and reading research papers on the health of migrants since this course heavily focuses on exploring and analyzing the research in the field.

Yes (although Professor Martnez will not be teaching the course - sad!)
I think that the content of this course is really important for all people (including health and non-health professionals, migrants and "non-migrants", etc.) to know. We touched on a variety of themes that all play a role in migration and health (broadly defined). I really loved this course and am sad to see Professor Martnez leave Yale.
Yes the material is relevant to today's world.
I would recommend this to other ER&M students.
